awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020: Mechanisms of Sensory-Motor Coordination in Zoospores of Pathogenic Chytrid Fungi
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The Fellow will investigate the relationship between detection of a target and movement towards the target by a pathogen (disease causing organism). These two systems are important for pathogenesis (disease); understanding how they evolve, and function together is crucial for creating treatments and preventing future epidemics. The chytrids are a group of single-celled fungi that have repeatedly emerged as pathogenic agents in vertebrates, invertebrates, plants, algae, and other fungi. This project will focus on the infectious life stage of chytrid fungi – revealing how they locate, navigate towards, and identify hosts. Currently, two species of chytrids are annihilating global amphibian populations in an epidemic that represents the greatest recorded loss of biodiversity due to a pathogen. Understanding how chytrids find and infect hosts will open new avenues to mitigate their current and future ecological impact while also advancing the understanding of parasite biology. Furthermore, chytrid fungi serve as a model for pathogenic epidemics that can destabilize ecosystems through the loss of biodiversity – potentially leading to increases in carriers of human disease and loss of normal ecosystem function. In addition to this research, the Fellow will work with outreach groups at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst to promote the inclusion and visibility of underrepresented groups in STEM.

Sensory and motor systems are linked through signal transduction pathways, allowing cells to coordinate behaviors with the external environment. Chytrid parasites have likely linked sensory and motor systems to find and identify hosts with devastating results. This project predicts that chytrid infection relies heavily on integrated sensory-motor pathways that can be disrupted. Through behavioral experiments, confocal and super-resolution microscopy, and phylogenetics, the Fellow will achieve two objectives. 1: determine if chytrids use diffusible chemical cues to identify and infect hosts. 2: identify the role broadly conserved signaling components play in guiding chytrid infectious behavior. This project will result in a deeper understanding of the sensory and motor pathways needed for chytrid infection and will answer broader questions about parasitism, pathogenicity, and sensory-motor coordination. The Fellow will collaborate with undergraduates from underrepresented groups to produce open-source educational material for teaching how light and vision have evolved and integrated with behavior in different animals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Sensory and motor systems are linked through signal transduction pathways, allowing cells to coordinate behaviors with the external environment. The fungal parasite Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) has likely linked sensory and motor systems to find and identify hosts with devastating results. The chytrid fungus Bd has led to the decline of many amphibians and represents a significant loss of biodiversity. The lethality of chytrid disease in amphibians is believed to be linked, in part, to the amount of Bd infecting a host. Because of this, reducing the rate of infection, replication, and host-Bd encounters may be vital in limiting mortality. Current host-specific approaches to mitigation have yet to produce a feasible strategy to control infection or lethality of chytrid disease.


In contrast, this project focused on the infectious life stage of chytrid fungi — revealing how they locate, navigate towards, and identify hosts. This project achieved two objectives: (1) determined that Bd uses diffusible chemical cues to locate and infect hosts and (2) identified the mechanisms guiding Bd motility during the infectious, zoosporic life stage. 


Understanding if and how Bd zoospores use host-associated chemical cues first required creating chemical gradients while imaging live cells. Accordingly, this project first developed a microfluidic assay that establishes stable, linear gradients and selected three potential chemical cues strongly associated with either host skin or actively infected hosts. Assessing zoospore responses, Dr. Swafford found that each of the three cues caused zoospores to aggregate towards the source of the cue, indicating they detect and respond to these host-associated cues in ways that would dramatically increase host-Bd encounters and likely infections. However, chemoattraction towards a cue can take two forms: chemotaxis and chemokinesis. Each of these mechanisms can use very different pathways. Therefore, before disrupting Bd chemoattraction is a possibility, we must understand how Bd guides its motility. 


Dr. Swafford used microscopy techniques and a new image analysis pipeline to discover that Bd responds to host-associated cues using chemotaxis and chemokinesis. This novel approach revealed that Bd differentiates between two cues, relying predominantly on chemotaxis for one cue but chemokinesis for the other. To verify these findings, this project produced a predictive chytrid behavior model. The model accurately simulates Bd behavior in response to gradients of the chosen cues on both short (seconds) and long (hours) timescales. Results from this project show that motility is a vital factor in chytrid infection strategy, and zoospores can use host-associated cues to bias their dispersal towards vulnerable hosts. 


Next, this project investigated how motility has evolved in these zoospores by developing a pipeline to investigate the gain, loss, and maintenance of functional gene clusters. Dr. Swafford identified patterns of gain and loss in the proteins necessary for crawling and new combinations of clusters involved in cilia function and development, which are necessary for swimming. However, understanding if these patterns correlate with the predicted functions demands experimental manipulation of the protein expression. To accomplish this, Dr. Swafford participated in developing molecular tools (transformation, exogenous molecule delivery, morpholinos) in Bd that enable future studies to label and manipulate the target proteins identified in our bioinformatic analysis.


Ongoing experiments from this project aim to develop transgenic strains of Bd to identify the molecular components behind zoospore chemotaxis and chemokinesis pathways. Additionally, this project will form the foundation for further work into understanding fungal diversity in chytrids and a deeper understanding of sensory systems, motor pathways, and how pathogenicity can arise from their integration and evolution. This project will have contributed to five peer-reviewed publications and will be the source of two peer-reviewed publications in the future. This project also contributed to the mentorship and professional development of students and scholars
